review.title: Technical Report: Graph-Structured Sparse Optimization for Connected Subgraph Detection
review.abstract: Structured sparse optimization is an important and challenging problem for analyzing high-dimensional data in a variety of applications such as bioinformatics, medical imaging, social networks, and astronomy. Although a number of structured sparsity models have been explored, such as trees, groups, clusters, and paths, connected subgraphs have been rarely explored in the current literature. One of the main technical challenges is that there is no structured sparsity-inducing norm that can directly model the space of connected subgraphs, and there is no exact implementation of a projection oracle for connected subgraphs due to its NP-hardness. In this paper, we explore efficient approximate projection oracles for connected subgraphs, and propose two new efficient algorithms, namely, Graph-IHT and Graph-GHTP, to optimize a generic nonlinear objective function subject to connectivity constraint on the support of the variables. Our proposed algorithms enjoy strong guarantees analogous to several current methods for sparsity-constrained optimization, such as Projected Gradient Descent (PGD), Approximate Model Iterative Hard Thresholding (AM-IHT), and Gradient Hard Thresholding Pursuit (GHTP) with respect to convergence rate and approximation accuracy. We apply our proposed algorithms to optimize several well-known graph scan statistics in several applications of connected subgraph detection as a case study, and the experimental results demonstrate that our proposed algorithms outperform state-of-the-art methods.

sections.text: The results indicate that our proposed method, GRAPH-GHTP and DepthFirstGraphScan, was the best on all three metrics for most settings. sections.heading: E. Scalability Analysis
sections.text: Table III and Table IV also show the comparison between our proposed method GRAPH-GHTP and other base methods at runtime. Results indicate that our proposed method GRAPH-GHTP ran faster in most settings than all base methods except EventTree. EventTree was the fastest method, but was unable to detect high-quality subgraphs. Since our method has a parameter at the upper limit (k) of the returned subgraph, we also performed the scalability of our method with respect to different values of k as shown in Figure 2. Results suggest that the runtime of our algorithm is insensitive to the setting of k, which is consistent with the time complexity analysis of GRAPH-GHTP, as described in Theorem II.5.

sections.text: A. The most important work comes from Hegde et al. [15]. Existing methods in this category fall into three main categories: 1) Exact algorithms. The latest method is a brunch-and-bounding algorithm DepthFirstGraphScan [36], which at worst expands exponentially; 2) Heuristic algorithms. Recent methods in this category include EventTree [32], NPHGS [8], AdditiveScan [37], GraphLaplacian [33] and EdgeLasso [34]; 3) Approximation algorithms that provide performance. Most of these methods are presented by the authors as quantum combination methods.

sections.heading: VII. CONCLUSION
sections.text: This paper presents GRAPH-IHT and GRAPH-GHTP, two efficient algorithms for optimizing a common nonlinear optimization problem that is subject to connectivity constraints. Extensive experiments demonstrate the effectiveness and efficiency of our algorithms. In the future, we plan to investigate other graph-structured constraints as connectivity constraints and expand our proposed methods so that good theoretical properties of cost functions that do not meet the WRSC condition can also be analyzed.

Although a number of structured sparsity models have been explored, such as trees, groups, clusters, and paths, connected subgraphs have been rarely explored in the current literature. One of the main technical challenges is that there is no structured sparsity-inducing norm that can directly model the space of connected subgraphs, and there is no exact implementation of a projection oracle for connected subgraphs due to its NP-hardness. In this paper, we explore efficient approximate projection oracles for connected subgraphs, and propose two new efficient algorithms, namely, GRAPH-IHT and GRAPH-GHTP, to optimize a generic nonlinear objective function subject to connectivity constraint on the support of the variables. Our proposed algorithms enjoy strong guarantees analogous to several current methods for sparsity-constrained optimization, such as Projected Gradient Descent (PGD), Approximate Model Iterative Hard Thresholding (AM-IHT), and Gradient Hard Thresholding Pursuit (GHTP) with respect to convergence rate and approximation accuracy. We apply our proposed algorithms to optimize several well-known graph scan statistics in several applications of connected subgraph detection as a case study, and the experimental results demonstrate that our proposed algorithms outperform state-of-the-art methods.
